status.full_text: @datenreisender @CodingBeing That there is an eslint rule is a good pointer that this behaviour is quite ambiguous...

@CodingBeing JavaScript is also compiled.

It's a decision made by the compiler author how this construct behaves.

@CodingBeing Right. So if this were code for a statically compile language, you would expect that it does not allow a try/catch/finally construct with two returns?

Wouldn't that be a complicated rule to not have a return in finally if there is one in try?

@gr2m @typescript Using TypeScript gets rid of an entire class of errors (how to properly call a function) and removes the need to test for proper arguments in the implementation of a function.
This removes a lot of code I need to write (and maintain) because of JS beeing an untyped language.

Firefox?
https://t.co/bmjfUmfDSx

@da_berni_ @gr2m @typescript If you call untyped code (which you have to declare explicitly as unsafe in TypeScript), you have no checks. 
But that is the your decision, not TypeScripts fault.

@da_berni_ @gr2m @typescript Right, it's the same.

Also note that there is a big difference between compile time type checking and runtime type checking!

I'm really psyched (as in @oredev's motto this year) to hear from @ladyleet and @robocell about the PAMStack: the principles to create inclusive architectures. https://t.co/gdziNF6dB5

Having a tech stack that enables meaningful contributions for all experience levels keeps the work on it exciting and rewarding,
and enables junior developers to grow more quickly.
#pamstack #oredev2019

Accessible architectures means having written and proven processes that are valid even in times of crisis.
Documentation of expected behaviour and past decisions helps to reduce confusion and ambiguity which ultimately lead to frustration.
#pamstack #oredev2019 https://t.co/Tf5imJrg4L

The #Angular CLI is a great example of useful abstractions that hides complexity away from developers which creates the ability for junior developers to build and ship valuable features without having to deal with the complexities of setting up an entire Angular app. #oredev2019 https://t.co/L1QqITerH5

Special mention by @ladyleet and @robocell of @typescript which makes authoring code so much more easier: #oredev2019 
üëè https://t.co/8nyFVBmkCK
@gr2m https://t.co/QSlZUsMVy1

Turn around your way of promoting employees and have them find a person within the organisation that can replace them. This gives a big incentive to seniors to start mentoring!
#pamstack #oredev2019

Juniors on the other hand can encourage mentoring from seniors by documenting their findings and asking about code, changes and processes they do not understand or feel could be explained better.
#pamstack #oredev2019

That was a super packed talk by @ladyleet and @robocell which you definitely should catch online or at a conference some time!
Slides: https://t.co/50HHROdVbW
#pamstack #oredev2019 https://t.co/AiDtSRa9SE

Product idea: inverted hiring platform where people looking for #remote positions have a profile and companies can apply.

This would raise awareness how many people prefer to work remote, and which jobs can be done remotely.

I also see that it's often possible for *some* teams withing a bigger organization, so visibility of this is often not great for applicants.

I wonder if there is a need for a https://t.co/KD8r0oBION like site, which is curated more like a tech conference, with tracks and a dedicated committee per track, that maintains and keeps a track up to date and relevant. 

I see that physical conferences are awesome, but $$$.

Physical conferences cater mostly towards an already privileged group of people, who have the money and time to attend.

But there seems to be no aggregation of the content that is shared there on a platform that offers some of the same quality checks and curation.
Committees ensure quality but also innovation, so that non-mainstream, but interesting or innovative topics get seen.

@raphaelfyi Thanks for saying that, you should have much more experience in that regard. 

I guess it needs to be made.
@miskaknapek The content is already there on classical remote job sites, maybe it could be curated better: https://t.co/5rFwrs76re

@Singsalad CloudWatch metrics is super powerful, so you would let your services publish these metrics and use the CloudWatch Logs dashboard to visualize them. You can use this from any infrastructure, even if you don't run on AWS.

@Singsalad Yes! E.g. I would use it to track and visualize business events like signups, and other user actions.
@Singsalad Basically you can publish your domain events there and then everyone can start building reports.
